summary.p: Five of the deputies from the individual German-speaking chapters of the [Bernese region] requested that the [Bernese] dispute be settled, and three urged that the truth, which was revealed at the [Bernese] Disputation [1528], be faithfully adhered to, and that all preachers in the future be bound to it by an oath; the [Small] Council assured all deputies that it would address this matter with the [Great] Council of the Two Hundred on Thursday [December 4]. The letter from the Zurich Council is also reserved for this day; it has already achieved much and threw the Bucerites into confusion; may God grant this matter a worthy outcome and may [His own in Bern] be delivered. Sulzer is upset about Megander's letter. Rümlang sends his regards to the people of Zurich.

div.p: Greetings. Deputies from the individual chapters of our German-speaking region have appeared, with representatives from five chapters requesting that the dispute among our preachers be settled, while three urged that the truth revealed and obtained in the Disputation be upheld, and that all preachers be bound by oath to prevent such occurrences in the future. All were dismissed with the response that the Senate, along with the Council of Two Hundred, intends to address this matter and set a date, namely Thursday after St. Andrew's Day, to hear everything related to this issue.

For this day, the writings of your Senate are also reserved, which have greatly advanced the matter and have considerably unsettled the Bucerites. We will pray to God to grant an outcome worthy of His glory and beneficial to us.
Farewell, everyone. Sulzer is indignant about Megander's letters. Keep me in your thoughts.
Given in Bern, on the 26th day of November in the year 1544. Entirely yours, Eberhard von Rümlang.
To the most honorable man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, primary pastor of the Zurich church, his ever-respected lord and patron.
